plugins/modules/network.py.message:
Hey, a question:
I see there are create_network methods both in cloud [1] and proxy [2]
Don't we need to change the args to `**attrs` form so that we end up using the proxy method and not the cloud one?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/master/openstack/cloud/_network.py#L458
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/master/openstack/network/v2/_proxy.py#L1724

yes, passing args like that is not going to work properly. What can be done, however, is: `self.conn.create_network(name=name, is_shared=shared, is_admin_state_up=admin_state_up, ...)`. But sure that passing single dict with attrs is going to be more flexible.
Maybe add a hint that an existing network will not be updated by this module?
Rename to is_shared and add shared as an alias, to match sdk?
Added a todo about changing module parameters to sdk names. Lets leave them for now, we have enough to do for now than worrying about module names.
I'd rather to leave it as is.
Rename to is_admin_state_up and add admin_state_up as an alias, to match sdk?
Rename to is_router_external and add external as an alias, to match sdk?
Rename to is_port_security_enabled and add port_security_enabled as an alias, to match sdk?

Better rename filters to args (to illustrate that this is a query arg, not a filter) and use

  self.conn.network.find_network(name_or_id=name, **args)
renamed to net_kwargs, coz it's a dictionary

We could save code with:
  if project_id:
    kwargs['project_id'] = project_id
  net = self.conn.network.create_network(name=name, ..., **kwargs)
Please document 'id' value in RETURN variable above.
OK, seems I figured this out.
Seems like it's impossible to add it, ansible-test complains.

plugins/modules/networks_info.py.message: check_versioned is supposed to check versions limitations of module options, and in module we have "name" and "filters" only, so it doesn't make sense to run it here.
Please change back to cloud layer because proxy layer does not support filters.

Another inconsistency in the SDK. When cloud layer network functions were ported to proxy objects, the (post) filtering functionality was dropped. Nowadays "filters" is really nothing more than "query" in openstack/cloud/_network.py[1]. This is only for network cloud functions though, for identity cloud functions filters can still be used to filter the results.

On other modules we decided to stick to filters arguments in order to keep as much functionality from the past as possible. This is not possible here, still i am inclined to keep it the "filters" argument for two reasons: consistency with other *_info modules and because sdk might readd postfiltering in the future.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/cloud/_network.py#L42

It's not filters, it's a "query" argument:
https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/master/openstack/network/v2/_proxy.py#L1794-L1815

Maybe worth to rename it to "query" to avoid confusing.
Ack, will change it back to cloud layer.
no need, it's None in function args: https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/fcd5be224c19cb99a80cf1820159454d6026e0b9/openstack/cloud/_network.py#L42

> Patch Set 1:

As mentioned in the zuul matrix room we can help you in #opendev on OFTC.

The problem is that the parent of this change (https://review.opendev.org/c/x/networking-infoblox/+/844193/13) and the grandparent of this change (https://review.opendev.org/c/x/networking-infoblox/+/843498/1) need to merge before this change can merge. Neither of those changes are currently mergeable because they have -1s from zuul.

Looking at these changes I think you may have meant for this change to be a new patchset on its parent rather than making a new change. But I'm not sure of that. Anyway that is why this one cannot merge. Gerrit won't let you merge a change until all of its parents merge first.

seems fine to me.
we do the same thing in sm-tools
https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/ha/+/789823/10/service-mgmt-tools/sm-tools/sm_tools/sm_api_msg_utils.py

default for decode is 'strict', but this appears safe

y = 'Helloé'
y.encode('ascii','ignore').decode()
'Hello'

y.encode('utf-8').decode()
'Helloé'
sm expect ascii. so please use ascii encoding. although it is very unlikely any characters is not ascii set, it still makes sense not to confuse with default utf8 encoding.

neutron/common/ovn/utils.py.message: Just one question: BM DHCP IPv6 is not supported. Should we fail here? Log that?

It will be logged already. As the options sent by Ironic will not match the ones from SUPPORTED_DHCP_OPTS_MAPPING (remember the SUPPORTED_BM_DHCP_OPTS_MAPPING mapping is a copy of that other mapping with the specific baremetal options, dnsmasq syntax, in it). 

So when IPv6 is used, our code will already detect that as a invalid option and it will be logged here: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/7fc509aa9aabf2e7c519d90570d9b56031abf0ab/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py#L658-L668

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message: thanks for explanation, I read a few times this method to understand it really

Thanks for reviewing!

Right yeah, this task is used to dynamically change the baremetal ports to enable and disable DHCP based on the configuration option. So it should run only once at the node that has the active lock.
I think we should add a note to remove this check in Z+4, right?

I don't think we should remove this. Because this maintenance task is to make sure that the configuration option is being honored.

If operator disables/enables the OVN built-in DHCP for baremetal ports we need this task to change the configuration on the ports itself.

Unless in the future we may think about removing this configuration option completely and always have OVN DHCP serving baremetals as the only option. Tho, from my experience working previously with Ironic I think many operators may want to plug their own DHCP server for baremetal, even Ironic does make it configurable because there are some crazy configurations that people may want have for PXE booting their hardware.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Can you provide any more detail. I have no idea what this review is doing based on this commit log.

To support the kernel sign feature, the packages 'kernel-std-signed' and 'kernel-rt-signed' in 'kernel/kernel-signed/' repo need to be built with 'build-pkgs' script,  but the premise is that the packages 'kernel-std' and 'kernel-rt' have been built done, so here set these sign packages with a new build type 'sign' with the lowest priority to make sure that these sign packages will be built in the last batch during 'distro' layer building. 

But according with the design of SODPPPG-60, since the customer will tailor their own sign workflow with their certificates/key in their script, these sign packages should not be built by default in 'build-pkgs --all' but only with 'build-pkgs -p <kernel-std-signed|kernel-rt-signed>' after they run their sign scripts, this is why the 'sign' build type is excluded by the depended commit: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/root/+/842662
Ack

$ mysql -u root
ERROR 1698 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost'

According to https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/authentication-plugin-unix-socket/ , the authentication is done by checking the uid of the process. Therefore, the command has to be run as root user.
Then I think we either need to add a step to su into root before running the command, or leave it as it was. I think it's better off leaving it as is.

I think this is a bad idea for a number of reasons. First, it changes the behavior with no microversion. Second, even with a microversion, it changes the default behavior during detach to something that probably isn't actually the most common use-case. You could argue, if we were adding detach from scratch now, which default makes the more sense. However, we have a long-lived default at this point and changing it to something (majority-desired, or not) is bad.

I think exposing the flag, or allowing you to declare intent when doing the detach (i.e. detach but please leave the port) is what we need to do. And, of course, a microversion for either :)

Wanted to put this up to have the discussion publicly, but after talking to Dan and gibi, we're leaning towards exposing preserve_on_delete for the VIFs, similar to how we have delete_on_termination for volumes. This allows clear communication of intent by the user on what they want done with the interface attachment.

so lookign in to this more i think this likely shoudl be a neutron api extension

we currently determin if we should preserve a prot on delete here 

_build_vif_model

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/d86916360858daa06164ebc0d012b78d19ae6497/nova/network/neutron.py#L3326-L3327=

if we had a new neutron api extion that allowed you to set a boolean flag to delete_on_detach  we coudl allow that to overried our default.

so the nova implemetaion woudl be something like this

preserve_on_delete = not current_neutron_port.get(
    'delete_on_detach',
    (current_neutron_port['id']  not in preexisting_port_ids)
)


the neutron side woudl be simiarly small jsut a new extended prot attrbute that can be set/unset and passed on port creation. 

addtion in nova we just need to make sure that we always check if we shoudl delete it by lookign a the vif object in the network info cache.

that is where we get the info today i think but i did not check fi we look it up for the network infor cache in all code paths where it matters.

i strongly think this is a bug that should be fixed without needing to opt into it but i get that this is a long lived default and we are stuck with it by the microversion rules.

its not documeted anywhere and as a customer i would consider this a bug if i encutored it and as a developer i really think is the incorrect behavior.
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=detach-interface-detail#detach-interface

no one should be depending on this behavior today as it not gurneteed by the api.
that siad someone probaly is.

if we go down the root of exposing a flag via a microverison i think we shoudl only do that if we default to not deleteing the port by default.

if people want the old behavior they can use the old microversion or override the new default with the flag on detach.

i dont think this shoudl be done as part of openstack server create in general.
if it was then we woudl have to ether stor this in the virtual_interfaces table or this shoudl be stored in the neutron port bining profile as a atribute of the port its self not in nova.


so to me this is either a bugfix and we proceed as artom has proposed where we do that the documetaion says and only detach and not delete on interface detach  or this is an RFE and we need a spec for the api change.
if we treat this as an RFE i think we shoudl do it properly and allow updating this on exsitng instance ports too to prempt the issue we had with cinder.

as much as i hate to say this by the micofverson rule i think this has to take the latter approch for backwards compatiblity so this will need a spec for the api change.

tbh, I still think we don't need it - as the VIP address is on the "master" node and thus that's why there was a split there already - the backups are fine to restart quickly; please elaborate further; also, this patch reintroduces the bug we had previously - that there are hanging connections being kept because of the lost VIP address

OK, let's split this thread in two.

1) There is no VIP on backups so there is nothing to trigger in keepalived - this is effectively a slower noop.

2) Yours is not default and helps in the general case (e.g., when the node dies). This trick was to let kernel send TCP RST for haproxy connections (thus your wait is irrelevant unless the TCP RST were dropped in the network). I guess we could rely on your and forget about this one but I don't see why we would want to change the order at all.

PS: That's why I wanted you to refactor this change, I felt it does something weird.

Reintroduces by which part ? 
Because if i remember hanging connections was fixed by me by ipv4.net.tcp.retries2 parameter in sysctl...

And I really  remember that I needed to split that logic.
I amended the code as I understood what you needed it for. I will rebase the other ones and have further inquiries on them. This one is gtg as far as I am concerned.
What I'm trying to say that I didn't change anything, just split handler Restart to stop and start. And it's because ansible is calling handlers serially.

1 
--------


Hmm, I am not sure If i remember correctly, but maybe the reason why I splitted this restart was switching balancer for mariadb (enable_proxysql: yes/no)

1. haproxy -> proxysql \
                           different order
2. Proxysql -> haproxy  /

Thant means, handlers are always called in some order for example in case:

- restart haproxy
- restart proxysql

1. This if fine, because services.d/mariadb is removed so haproxy is restarted and then proxysql is started with listening on 3306.

2. Proxysql is listening 3306 but ansible is calling handlers in order defined above, so services.d/mariadb is defined ..haproxy is restarted, but this will fail  because proxysql is not restarted and it is just going to be restarted in second handler call, but this of course - will fail.

When it is 

- Stop haproxy
- Stop proxysql
- Start haproxy
- Start proxysql

ok, that was not the problem. tobiko already calculates that. The ping size (-s value) is calculated to send patckets with the mtu size; i.e.: if size=mtu=1500, the command used is ping -s 1472

tacker/tests/functional/common/fake_gran.message: It seems that the Copyright notation is missing.
I think "specified VIM is missing" is better.
This route should also pass if `vim_list` is not empty, so "vim_list is Empty" is not suitable.

nit: I think it is less than 80 characters without line break.

Is it not necessary to change the URL used in v1 FT as well?
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/830932/18/.zuul.yaml#304
"http://127.0.0.1:9990/grant/v1/grants"
-> "http://127.0.0.1:9990/v1/grant/v1/grants"

Both v1 API and v2 API of Tacker use Grant v1, but what is the reason for separating grant definitions for v1 API and v2 API?
(Currently, using grant_v2, both FT for v1 API and FT for v2 API seem to pass the test.)

This file is used for manual testing of separated NFVO to simulate the return value on the NFVO side. It has nothing to do with the return value of FT.

If v1 and v2 use the same URL, when tacker sends grant requests to NFVO, it goes to the same API and returns the same content.

However, v1 and v2 are not exactly the same. According to the current implementation code, the key of the vim-related return value in v1 is 'vimConnections', and the key of the vim-related return value in v2 is 'vimConnectionInfo'. So grant requests for v1 and v2 can only be processed separately with different urls.

Since the Grant URL of V1 is a complete URL and can be customized by users, the URL of V1 is modified so that the case where v1 and V2 both use separated NFVO can return the correct value separately.

Thank you for your polite explanation.
I was able to understand that this file has nothing to do with FT.
I also confirmed the difference between SOL003 v2.6.1 and v3.3.1 in the Grant definition.

I'm not sure if this is the best method, but I think it's okay if at least manual testing is the target.
I agree with your policy.
Thank you for your time.

I don't think this is immediately intuitive. Traditionally, our undercloud and overclouds have operated entirely independently from a configuration perspective. ie, users would define any settings they want for the overcloud in their environment files rather than relying on any configuration from the undercloud.

The fact that we were defaulting to the undercloud ctlplane-subnet dns_nameservers I don't think has been overtly obvious to our users and customers.

I get the technical limitation, and that we need to handle this prior to stack creation now, so +1 for this change. But I think maybe we might need to consider adding an option to either the networks_data_v2 file, or the file used to provision the baremetal nodes. Kind of similar to how we're doing it here for the default route network:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/baremetal-samples/baremetal_deployment.yaml#L20

Maybe another option for:
```
 default_dns_nameservers:
 - 1.1.1.1
 - 8.8.8.8
```

> I don't think this is immediately intuitive. Traditionally, our undercloud and overclouds have operated entirely independently from a configuration perspective. ie, users would define any settings they want for the overcloud in their environment files rather than relying on any configuration from the undercloud.
> 

IMO that is problematic, we allowed users to put dns servers and gateway addresses for a subnet in undercloud.conf, and then the values could be overridden in overcloud environment. So what you have in undercloud.conf and neutron resource properties are not equal to what is on deployed nodes. Confusing, make troubleshooting harder etc.

> The fact that we were defaulting to the undercloud ctlplane-subnet dns_nameservers I don't think has been overtly obvious to our users and customers.
> 

I agree we probably failed to document/communicate this well.

> I get the technical limitation, and that we need to handle this prior to stack creation now, so +1 for this change. But I think maybe we might need to consider adding an option to either the networks_data_v2 file, or the file used to provision the baremetal nodes. Kind of similar to how we're doing it here for the default route network:
> https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/baremetal-samples/baremetal_deployment.yaml#L20
> 
> Maybe another option for:
> ```
>  default_dns_nameservers:
>  - 1.1.1.1
>  - 8.8.8.8
> ```

I don't agree. :) Because ...

  If the users are forced to change how they define nameservers, it does not matter if that is "set dns_nameservers on the subnet in 'undercloud.conf'" or set 'default_dns_nameservers' in network_data/baremetal_deployment YAML's.

  Also, implementing such an override is complex, changes in tripleo-ansible, tripleo-common and tripleo-heat-templates. Adding back conditions/complexity in THT which I removed in the next patch in this chain.

I will leave this unresolved, for other reviewers to chime in as well.

That is a fair point. If we're already asking them to define it somewhere, then we shouldn't need them to define it again later in Heat environment files.

As long as we document it in the undercloud install guide; that the DNS server they define in the undercloud.conf file, will be used for the overcloud nodes as well. And again in the overcloud deploy guide as a note when we talk about network configuration. That should be enough to address any confusion that might come from users.
To be clear, this deprecation will be backported to wallaby and the follow removal is only for master?

For any stable release testing, we have a range of tempest compatible versions
- https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/tempest_and_plugins_compatible_version_policy.html

So for stable/ussuri we can use Tempest 23.0.0 to 31.0.0. i do not like this approch since it does not fulfile use-case 2


* As a nova developer, I would like to have feature parity in the compute API
  for volume-backed and image-backed servers.

if i need to pass an addtional paramter to do this then its not feature partity its two similar but not identical feature.

just as we now hide block vs non block migration behind an auto flag i think nova shoudl jsut handel this internally.

we know if an instance is BFV or not we can use that to determin what code path to take and just remove the api block.

as a user i should not need to care if my instance is BFV or not if i do i think this feature has failed to provide partiy.

im not sure we need an api micorverison to change from a 400 to a 200 either by the way.

reading lees previous comment i dont aggree with it.

if the intent is to provide partiy for exsitng behavior then we shoudl not intodocue a new parmater.

those two constriats are on conflict.

the user requsted a rebuild so we shoudl do what they said.

the expection of no boot form volume root disks is also that they are persitent.

we do not consider the root disk to be part of the instnaces ephmearl storage. it is persitent storage just as much as a cinder volume is espically if you use the rbd images backend or mount the instnace state dir on shared storage. 

even if you are using just qcow wiht no distributed storage its sill persitent storage.
we discussed this at lenght on irc and the spec has now been updted to relect the outcome of that converstaion so marking this comment thread as resolved.

This has already been discussed in great lengths in the original spec where the latest occurrence of this question asked by Gorka and reply by Lee is here[1]
tl;dr volumes have a precedent to be persistent storage and this will destroy all the data on the volume that is why an extra caution step is added here.
Lee suggested this option and Dan Smith suggested on the proposed changes to make this parameter travel down from api to conductor to the compute layer.

I don't mind removing the use case 2 since it carries less value than providing the actual feature in a more precautionary way.

neutron/objects/db/api.py.message: What about this one, should the method have the writer decorator?

This method call, same as in other places in this module, is done inside a DB context. In this case created in L117.

I've refactored some of those private methods in other modules and I try to add the decorator just in the public method, to avoid nesting them.

I just thought about it, shall we write a few lines of contributor guideline how to use these decorators, how we use them now, etc ?
I thought of things like:
* order of these decorators
* to which method decorate in the call chain
* even trivial things like when to use READER/WRITER contexts
* mix with retry decorators
* I don't know....

Ah no, the DB contexts are both context managers and decorators. There is no difference between both. It is usually cleaner to use the decorator but in this case I see no need to change the existing code.
Give me some time and I'll push a patch. For sure we need something in the contributors guide to provide some tips about how to access to the DB.

No, if no password is provided then the barbican secret query returns no secrets. In this case mtcAgent will fail the secret fetch and produce these logs and retry every 10 seconds until the password is available.

2022-06-01T10:46:55.557 [971410.01097] controller-0 mtcAgent pwd secretUtil.cpp    ( 449) secretUtil_handler      :Error : storage-1 no barbican secret reference found : {"secrets": [], "total": 0} (107)
2022-06-01T10:46:55.562 [971410.01098] controller-0 mtcAgent pwd secretUtil.cpp    ( 252) secretUtil_manage_secret: Warn : storage-1 failed to get secret reference

A bmc access failure alarm will be raised after 2 minutes

| 200.010  | storage-1 access to board management module has failed.                     | host=storage-1                        | warning  | 2022-06-01T10:48:15.     |
|          |                                                                             |                                       |          | 305858                   |

The previous code would produce no mtcAgent error logs suggesting there was a missing password but the alarm would still be raised.

This is improved handling.

        if output and len(res:=output.split()[0].split('/')) == 2:

This may need to share the same lock as create_snapshot() etc this driver.  Needs a closer look.

What happens if create_snapshot is calling to Nova for an attached volume and this happens at the same time?

So, the same lock in L577 will be sufficient?

    @coordination.synchronized('{self.driver_prefix}-{snapshot.volume.id}')

Oops, I don't have `snapshot` argument in this method. So I'd need

This log needs to be after the "return" at 384 to prevent confusion.
TODO(lseki): check if this also works with a shutoff VM. If it doesn't, add a condition to check VM power state.

You don't actually need this. The nova side extend_volume already handles both the extend of attached and encrypted volume.

Once you check if the volume can be extended bellow, you can just return if attached.

As mentioned in the etherpad, Nova will not perform the resize if the volume is attached to a shutoff instance. However, libvirt will release the lock on the volume file on shutoff, so Cinder can then use qemu-img resize.
Because Cinder does not know the instance state, we need to try to resize even if the volume is attached, in case the instance is in shutoff state.

I have a suggestion
If attached, just return, do not execute qemu-img resize.

See my reply to Erlon R. Cruz.
We need to try to resize anyway, in case that the volume is attached to a shutoff instance.

The schema is a Python tree-like structure where nodes are pattern matched against corresponding trees of values.

puppet-ovn is setting the value for the bridges provided in the bridge mappings parameter, where as this patch is setting it for all OvsBridges. 

IMO, the provider bridges will be part of the bridge maaping, which ovn should already take care of. Is this required for non-ovn scenarios?

Thanks for your input, those are great points. As for the first question - the puppet-ovn settings are not persistent across reboots because networks scripts delete and re-create the OVS bridge, thus the configuration is lost.

As for the second point, it is required for OVN, I'll have a look. However, I don't think having such setting on all bridges will cause any harm as the option will just be ignored. But I'll try to come up with better solution, I'm not familiar much with os-net-config :)

Can you capture the first point in the commit msg too. 

I am OK to applying it to all ovs bridges, the only addition added use case would be the tenant bridge (which may or may not be added to bridge mapping). But I am fine it, it does not harm.

I am not sure if the same is required in case of DPDK (OvsUserBridge). Do you have any idea on that? The current puppet implementation will apply for all bridges on bridge mapping, DPDK bridges also will be part of it.

This may be pretty surprising to people who are running this on a more general-purpose machine (i.e. a laptop) who don't expect something so fundamental to have changed.

That said, devstack installs things running with privileges that are user-writable as a pretty important part of the workflow so it's probably not critical.

The important thing that needs to change is just the execute bit so that other things can traverse right? Maybe it would be better to just set ugo+x on ~ to avoid exposing the contents of the home directory without restricting the ability to traverse to specific things?

Wrt executable thing, from what i recall yes it should be enough, i will cross check if need to update here. The reason i pushed 755 change so it have same permissions as before(previous distro releases) and just work.

Personally I think that this is ok as devstack isn't something what people usually install on their main machines. I think it's even written somewhere in devstack docs that it is prettily "intrusive" and may make many changes in the environment.
I checked it works fine with just chmod +x, so updated the patch according to it.

specs/zed/approved/libvirt-viommu-device.message:
Another thing we need to do is add `<locked/>` to `<memoryBacking>`.  The reason behind that is that when using vIOMMU, the MEMLOCK_RLIMIT will be hit, read more here:

https://listman.redhat.com/archives/vfio-users/2018-July/msg00001.html

> I'm guessing you're assigning multiple devices to the same VM, which
doesn't work well with a guest IOMMU currently.  The trouble is that
with a guest IOMMU, each assigned device has a separate address space
that is initially configured to map the full address space of the VM
and each vfio container for each device is accounted separately.
libvirt will only set the locked memory limit to a value sufficient for
locking the memory once, whereas in this configuration we're locking it
once per assigned device.  Without a guest IOMMU, all devices run in
the same address space and therefore the same container, and we only
account the memory once for any number of devices.

We ran into this in our testing, by adding `<locked/>`, we're removing all of the limits (this is similar to how it was handled when SEV was implemented).
I think you mean `model` here, and I guess we should add a detail that the flavour property would be something like `hw:viommu_model` instead

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Change this to

Debian: puppet-manifests: do not call grubby to edit grub.cfg
Done

LAT/Debian does allow editing the grub.cfg, just not at runtime since it is a file tracked by OSTree. I would suggest the above paragraph be reworded somewhat
---
The grub.cfg file is including in OSTree images and may be signed as part of secure boot, as such it is not to be edited on the target. Modifications to grub.cfg can be affected by changing the template used by LAT during image building. Runtime changes, such as those applied previously by tools like 'grubby' must now be managed via variable substitution in grub.cfg and using boot/efi/EFI/BOOT/boot.env. Update instances of using grubby that edited grub.cfg to using this alternative approach.
---
Done

Hongxu, I don't see your response to why you went the path of writing python code.

I am afriad grub-editenv could not satisfy the requirement, our needs
is to modify grub variable `kernel_params' in boot.env, add/remove part
of the content.
...
sysadmin@controller-0:~$ cat /boot/efi/EFI/BOOT/boot.env 
# GRUB Environment Block
kernel_params= iommu=pt nmi_watchdog=panic,1 softlockup_panic=1 intel_iommu=on biosdevname=0 user_namespace.enable=1 hugepagesz=2M hugepages=0 default_hugepagesz=2M rcu_nocbs=2-31,34-63 kthread_cpus=0-1,32-33 irqaffinity=2-31,34-63 audit=0 audit_backlog_limit=8192 nopti nospectre_v2 nospectre_v1
ab=0
boot_tried_count=0
ostree_console=console=ttyS1,115200 console=tty1 console=ttyS1,115200 console=tty1
...

Such as the following boot.env, if we want to remove/add hugepagesz and
hugepages from it, we could not use grub-editenv to do it. The grub-editenv
only edit boot.env to add/remove kernel_params as a whole

1) Remove kernel_params
sysadmin@controller-0:~$ grub-editenv ./boot.env unset kernel_params

sysadmin@controller-0:~$ grub-editenv ./boot.env list
ab=0
boot_tried_count=0

2) Add/Set kernel_params
sysadmin@controller-0:~$ grub-editenv ./boot.env set kernel_params="iommu=pt hugepagesz=2M hugepages=0 default_hugepagesz=2M nopti"

sysadmin@controller-0:~$ grub-editenv ./boot.env list
ab=0
boot_tried_count=0
kernel_params=iommu=pt hugepagesz=2M hugepages=0 default_hugepagesz=2M nopti

The key is to edit string `iommu=pt hugepagesz=2M hugepages=0
default_hugepagesz=2M nopti', to add/remove sub string (kernel param)
from it, I've tried sed/grep in my original fix, but failed with exception
for the expression of sed. That's why I choose python3 to do it

We either need to rename "puppet-update-boot-env.sh" or make this script generic (ie. to not only handle kernel params)

We are going to have to edit more than 'kernel_params' with puppet, for example to switch between standard and rt kernel types. So ideally this script can allow for all edits of boot.env. If functions for handling 'kernel_params' are desirable as it is special, then we can have them but they should use the generic functions to complete their work.

The naming refers script puppet-update-default-grub.sh [1] which is a script to edit GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX in /etc/default/grub. Both of them do the very similar operation.

For kernel type setting, I suggest we provide a new script to do it, because the param is saved to another file (/boot/1/kernel.env or /boot/2/kernel.env) [2]
...
root@intel-x86-64:~# cat /boot/1/kernel.env 
# GRUB Environment Block
kernel=vmlinuz-5.10.0-13-rt-amd64
kernel_rollback=vmlinuz-5.10.0-13-rt-amd64
...
The reason why I do it in /boot/1/kernel.env other than /boot/efi/EFI/BOOT/boot.env:
- /boot/efi/EFI/BOOT/boot.env could not be updated after ostree upgrade, we add extra operation to edit it;
- /boot/1/kernel.env is along with kernel, and could be updated with kernel image after ostree upgrade, it is done automatically, no more extra operation


[1] https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/branch/master/puppet-manifests/src/bin/puppet-update-default-grub.sh
[2] https://github.com/Wind-River/meta-lat/commit/8ec7c6a786758d22d90918846c359681524b985c
I would still like to see a generic script to handle wrapping grub-editenv. If we don't do this then we will repeat code which is not ideal, we end up maintaining duplicate code.

doc/source/reference/storage/external-ce.message: Are you sure that does the trick? I think cephadm is running services in containers, are they bind mounting those dirs or something similar?

Even if this fixes an issue (would be nice to see details of the issue being fixed), /etc/kolla/certificates/private/ is not the correct location to find the CA cert. It might be in /etc/kolla/certificates/ca/ if you are copying it to the kolla containers, but it might not.

Also, /etc/kolla/certificates/ca/ would be on the Ansible control host. Which host(s) need to trust the CA to fix your issue?

Hi, the problem is with Ceph not being a Kolla container, so certificates are not copied to the container (these are self-signed certs made from Kolla) and consequently SSL certificate issues arise.  The easiest way to solve this problem is to make the host recognize the certificates locally, that way Ceph will also recognize them regardless of how Ceph is installed (Podman, Docker, Ansible, etc). In my installation, I have TLS enabled in everything with Kolla (see below my TLS options):

`kolla_enable_tls_internal: "yes"
kolla_enable_tls_external: "yes"
kolla_enable_tls_backend: "tes"
rabbitmq_enable_tls: "yes"
kolla_copy_ca_into_containers: "yes"
openstack_cacert: "{{{{ '/etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt' if kolla_enable_tls_external == 'yes' else '' }}}}"
`

With regards to the cert file location, '/etc/kolla/certificates/ca/root.crt' and '/etc/kolla/certificates/private/root/root.crt' are identical. Depending on what TLS is enabled for the end-user, they may need to import additional SSL certificates.  Importing only the root.crt did not work for me which is why I referenced the private folder instead of the ca folder. The private folder has the benefit of having the root folder but also the internal, external, and backend certificates (folders) available.  It may be possible to import only a subset of the certificates, but I didn't want to explicitly say import a certificate that they do not have/use it.
Yes, without issuing that command, I would get SSL cert errors.  Once updated, I could communicate properly.

class TestOVSPlugin(testscenarios.WithScenarios,
                   base.VifPlugOvsBaseFunctionalTestCase):

 def setUp(self):
        super(TestOVSPlugin, self).setUp()
        run_privileged('ovs-vsctl', 'set-manager', 'ptcp:6640')
        self.plugin = ovs.OvsPlugin.load(constants.PLUGIN_NAME)
        self.flags(ovsdb_interface=self.interface, group='os_vif_ovs')

        self.ovs = ovsdb_lib.BaseOVS(CONF.os_vif_ovs)
        self._ovsdb = self.ovs.ovsdb

        self.profile_ovs = objects.vif.VIFPortProfileOpenVSwitch(
            interface_id='e65867e0-9340-4a7f-a256-09af6eb7a3aa',
            datapath_type='netdev')

        self.vif_vhostuser_trunk = objects.vif.VIFVHostUser(
            id='b679325f-ca89-4ee0-a8be-6db1409b69ea',
            address='ca:fe:de:ad:be:ef',
            network=self.network_ovs_trunk,
            path='/var/run/openvswitch/vhub679325f-ca',
            mode='client',
            port_profile=self.profile_ovs)

        self.instance = objects.instance_info.InstanceInfo(
            name='demo',
            uuid='f0000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001')

    def _check_bridge(self, name):
        return self._ovsdb.br_exists(name).execute()

    def _add_bridge(self, name, may_exist=True, datapath_type=None):
        self._ovsdb.add_br(name, may_exist=may_exist,
                           datapath_type=datapath_type).execute()
        self.assertTrue(self._check_bridge(name))

    def _del_bridge(self, name):
        self._ovsdb.del_br(name).execute()

    def test_unplug_ovs_vhostuser_trunk(self, delete_ovs_vif_port,
                                        delete_ovs_bridge):
        trunk_bridge = '%s01' % constants.TRUNK_BR_PREFIX
        self.plugin.plug(self.vif_vhostuser_trunk, self.instance)
        # this should not be requried but just in cases unplug brakes
        self.addCleanup(self._del_bridge, trunk_bridge)

        # assert that  trunk bride bridges are created here
        self.assertTrue(self._check_bridge(trunk_bridge))

        other_bridge = 'br-%s' %  uuidutils.generate_uuid()
        self._add_bridge(other_bridge)
        self.addCleanup(self._del_bridge, other_bridge)
        self.plugin.unplug(self.vif_vhostuser_trunk, self.instance)
        self.assertTrue(self._check_bridge(other_bridge))
        self.assertFalse(self._check_bridge(trunk_bridge))

oslo_db/sqlalchemy/engines.py.message:
this is already a pre-ping handler here, which is the first version of the "legacy" pre ping handler you see at https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/pooling.html#custom-legacy-pessimistic-ping , that eventually became a built in feature.

So two/three things:

1. if we have pre-ping as an option, it should disable this event listener here and 

2. oslo.db sets "pre-ping" on unconditionally for all projects via this event handler.   do we think it's time to use the new "pre-ping" exclusively instead, remove the old handler, and therefore we don't need this option?

3. note that the MySQL pre-ping handler uses connection.ping(), which is a driver-specific feature, and doesn't do all the "on disconnect error" stuff.  this is a good thing, but it's a change in how this would work.
